title: Academic self-concept and academic interest measurement: A multi-sample European study
abstract: Academic self-concept and academic interest are crucial concepts for understanding students' academic achievement. Yet, few questionnaires currently exist that have been used and validated in more than one country. This study aimed at assessing these concepts using an academic self-concept questionnaire (Marsh, 1990) and an academic interest questionnaire (Corbière & Mbekou, 1997) with French and Italian student samples. Confirmatory Factor Analyses enabled us to assess the structure of the two questionnaires with regard to two academic subjects-Math and First Language (French or Italian)-and to determine the theoretical directions between the concepts. Results from Confirmatory Factor Analyses of both French and Italian samples supported a theoretical model in which academic self-concept and academic interest were intercorrelated, yet maintaining their unique characteristics. On the other hand, results from Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analyses (French and Italian samples) endorsed a correlational model between the two concepts. Finally, the results indicated a significant and positive correlation between academic self-concept, academic interest, and academic achievement in both academic subjects.

abstract.text: Academic self-concept and academic interest are crucial concepts for understanding students' academic achievement. Yet, few questionnaires currently exist that have been used and validated in more than one country. This study aimed at assessing these concepts using an academic self-concept questionnaire (Marsh, 1990) and an academic interest questionnaire (Corbière & Mbekou, 1997) with French and Italian student samples. Confirmatory Factor Analyses enabled us to assess the structure of the two questionnaires with regard to two academic subjects-Math and First Language (French or Italian)-and to determine the theoretical directions between the concepts. Results from Confirmatory Factor Analyses of both French and Italian samples supported a theoretical model in which academic self-concept and academic interest were intercorrelated, yet maintaining their unique characteristics. On the other hand, results from Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analyses (French and Italian samples) endorsed a correlational model between the two concepts. Finally, the results indicated a significant and positive correlation between academic self-concept, academic interest, and academic achievement in both academic subjects.

body_text.text: Factors contributing to academic achievement have been studied extensively for many years, with certain concepts emerging as more influent than others such as academic selfconcept and academic interest. In this introduction, a definition of both concepts is provided and the links between academic self-concept, academic interest and academic achievement are also presented. academic self-concept, the skill development theory (Skaalvik & Hagvet, 1990 ), (2) academic self-concept predicts academic achievement, the self-enhancement theory (Shavelson & Bolus, 1982) and, (3) the two concepts affect each other reciprocally, the reciprocal model (Liu & Kaplan, 1992; Marsh & Yeung, 1997) . Results stemming from longitudinally designed studies have primarily supported the reciprocal model, with authors further emphasizing the need to intervene on improving students' academic self-concept in order to help them meet their academic goals (Guay, Marsh, & Boivin, 2003; Marsh & Yeung, 1997) . With respect to academic interest, a meta-analysis conducted by Schiefele and Csikszentmihalyi (1994) has illustrated the significant relationship between academic interest and academic achievement. Based on results from 16 empirically sound studies, Schiefele and Csikszentmihalyi (1994) detected a significant mean correlation coefficient value (r=.31) between the two targeted concepts. The results also suggested that academic interest and academic achievement were linked for all academic subjects (i.e., Mathematics, Science, Physics, Social Science, Literature, etc.) . Furthermore, another study indicates a reciprocal relationship between academic interest and academic achievement (Corbière, 1998) .

cite_spans.text: Mathematics, Science, Physics, Social Science, Literature, etc.)

body_text.text: In brief, both concepts (i.e., academic self-concept and academic interest) evaluated as distinct or joint academic concepts, predict academic achievement when the specific academic subject is taken into consideration. Furthermore, results to date suggest that these two concepts might be intercorrelated and together might strongly contribute to understanding academic achievement.

Except for recent studies conducted in France (Guérin, Marsh, & Famose, 2003) and Germany (Marsh & Köller, 2004 ) supporting the theoretical model that distinguishes specific self-concept subject areas such as Math and Verbal self-concepts, there is a paucity of information about students' interests and academic self-concept for European students. Since most validated instruments in education stem from Australia and North America, the investigation of these concepts using validated instruments in Western Europe (e.g., France and Italy) is necessary in order to better understand academic achievement across educational systems. Furthermore, Cokley, Komarraju, King, Cunningham, and Muhammad (2003) mention that it is possible to observe ethnic differences in the measurement of academic selfconcept. In their study, the factor structure of the academic self-concept was different in African Americans when compared to European Americans. The analysis of instruments across languages is also important in order to verify the structural invariance of the questionnaires in different linguistic versions.

cite_spans.text: Cokley, Komarraju, King, Cunningham, and Muhammad (2003)

body_text.text: Consequently, the objectives of this study are fourfold: (1) to perform descriptive analyses of measures of academic interest (Corbière & Mbekou, 1997) and academic selfconcept (Marsh, 1990 ) specifically related to Math and First Language (French or Italian); (2) to validate the presence or absence of relationships between Academic interest and Academic self-concept questionnaires with French and Italian students by using Confirmatory Factorial Analysis (CFA); (3) to verify the structural invariance of Academic interest and Academic self-concept questionnaires with both samples by using Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analysis (MCFA); and (4) to study the relationships between Academic interest, Academic self-concept questionnaires, and academic achievement.

The study was conducted with two samples of students respectively enrolled in French and Italian high schools. The student sample from France consisted of 153 boys and 162 girls with an average age of 12.39 years (SD: .87). In terms of educational level, 159 were attending the U.S. equivalent of sixth grade and 156, seventh grade. The student sample from Italy included 450 boys and 543 girls, aged between 18 and 19. In terms of educational level, 247 students were enrolled in a regular high school, 488 were following a technical training, and 258 were attending a secondary school with a professional training.

In both samples, the same four questionnaires were used to assess academic interest and academic self-concept for Math and First Language, with only the content of First Language being different (French or Italian). As recommended for cross-cultural validations (Vallerand, 1989) , the Academic self-concept questionnaire was translated into French and Italian whereas the Academic interest questionnaire was translated from French to Italian and English by professional translators. The bilingual authors of this article back-translated it and compared the original version of the four questionnaires to back-translations of the English or French translations. Very few modifications to the French/Italian/English translations had to be made since the back-translations were practically identical to the original English or French versions.

Data collection was made with students enrolled in one high school from the South of France and one from North Italy. For each classroom (around 20-40 students), two research assistants explained the research project to the students in a similar manner.

The academic interest questionnaire (Corbière & Mbekou, 1997) assesses academic interest terms that are defined by different authors (Eccles, 1983; Schiefele & Csikszentmihalyi, 1994; Viau, 1994) . Rated on a five-point Likert scale (1=completely disagree; 5=completely agree), six items measure three aspects of preferences for specific subject areas (in this case Math and First Language): inherent positive feelings, intrinsic motivation (Schiefele & Csikszentmihalyi, 1994) , and the perceived usefulness and importance of achieving in each targeted academic subject. The items are described in Appendix (in English, French and Italian).

The academic self-concept (Marsh, 1990) questionnaire consists of six items and uses a five-point Likert-type scale (1=completely disagree; 5=completely agree) to assess academic self-concept in each of the targeted school subjects: Math and First Language (French/Italian, see Appendix). For example, one of the items is: "Compared to others my age I am good at Math". Initially the questionnaire consisted of a six-point Likert type scale but was adjusted to a five-point Likert-scale for the academic interest questionnaire in order to facilitate the completion of both questionnaires.

Academic achievement was self-reported by French students with respect to their grades in Math and French. In the French school system, grades range from 0 (the worst grade) to 20 (the best grade). Since the grades were self-reported, the class president was asked to verify the grades mentioned by the students from his/her classroom. The class president was a representative of his/her classroom who had access to the grades of his/her classmates. Occasionally, when there was a disagreement between the self-reported grade and the report of the class president, both grades were reviewed to establish an agreement on the actual mark. Consequently, the self-reported grades of students could then be evaluated as reliable grades.

Statistical analyses involved four steps. First, in order to describe the Academic interest (Corbière & Mbekou, 1997) and Academic self-concept (Marsh, 1990) questionnaires, preliminary descriptive analyses (range, mean, standard deviation, and Cronbach alpha coefficients) were carried out on the French and Italian samples. Second, Confirmatory Factor Analyses with French and Italian samples enabled verification of the factorial structure of each questionnaire according to the following models: (a) distinct academic concepts without intercorrelations, (b) intercorrelation between the two academic concepts, and (c) one single dimension accounting for both academic concepts. Third, by considering the results from the previous CFA, Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analysis (MCFA) was performed to test the invariance across the two samples. Fourth, correlations between all questionnaires from both samples, Italian and French, were examined. Moreover, correlations between the two academic concepts and the academic achievement were calculated for the French sample.

MCFA is a method for detecting construct bias across different samples (Keith, Fugate, DeGraff, Diamond, Shadrach, & Stevens, 1995; Keith, Quirk, Schartzer, & Elliott, 1999) . MCFA not only offers several tests from unconstrained to very constrained, but it also offers statistical fit-indices, which provide objective methods for deciding on the presence or absence of differences between groups. In other words, MCFA permits testing of different equivalence levels between samples (in this case, French and Italian samples). Within MCFA, a hierarchical procedure is available in order to establish the equivalence between groups. First, the most critical aspect of factor invariance evaluated across groups is related to factor loadings, particularly, whether the loadings are equal between the groups. Second, another important equivalence is the factors' correlation, because it suggests that the factors or components are interrelated in the same way across groups. Third, the invariance of item error variances is optional because it is possible to observe variations among respondents from different countries. This entire hierarchical procedure was followed in this study.
body_text.section: Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) and Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analysis (MCFA)

body_text.text: Before conducting MCFA, authors strongly recommend that the test model be validated without any constraints (Bentler, 1995; Kenny, 2000) . This unconstrained model is conceptually equivalent to conducting CFA with one sample. In this direction, the abovementioned three models had been tested with French and Italian samples, with the best fitting model considered most valid and subsequently retained for MCF analyses.
body_text.section: Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) and Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analysis (MCFA)

body_text.text: Using the EQS Software (Bentler, 1995) for the CFA and the MCFA, the evaluation of the models' fit with the empirical data was carried out by taking into account various statistical indices. The adjustment indices such as the Chi square/degrees of freedom ratio, the "Normed Fit Index" (NFI), the "NonNormed Fit Index" (NNFI), the Comparative Fit Index, robust CFI (calculated starting from the Satorra-Bentler Chi square), the Bollen Incremental Fit Index (IFI), as well as the RMSEA (Root Mean Standard Error of Approximation) were used to measure the fit of the models. With regards to the value criterion of these indices, the Chi square/degrees of freedom ratio must be close to 5 (Byrne, 1989; Hofmann, 1995) , the NFI, NNFI, CFI, IFI, and robust CFI must be higher than .90 and the RMSEA must be close to .05 so that the model has good fit (Jöreskog & Sörbom, 1993; Mueller, 1996) . With regards to the CFA, the estimation method Maximum Likelihood-Robust (ML-Robust) was utilized in order to evaluate the different abovementioned models. In absence of specific recommendations for MCFA, the same fit-indices and their cut-off values for single group analysis as described above were used -except for the Robust CFI, which is not available because only the ML estimation method was used for MCFAs.
body_text.section: Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) and Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analysis (MCFA)

body_text.text: For the French and Italian samples, descriptive analyses revealed mean scores in Academic interest ranging from 18.07 (SD=6.19) to 24.04 (SD=4.38), and in Academic selfconcept from 18.82 (SD=6.31) to 22.79 (SD=5.35) ( Table 1 ). The internal consistency coefficients for the academic interest and academic self-concept (Math and Italian/French) questionnaires were all satisfactory with alphas from .73 to .89 (Table 1) . Confirmatory factor analyses were carried out on both French and Italian samples, using the following questionnaires: Academic interest and Academic self-concept in Math (12 items), and Academic interest and Academic self-concept in French or Italian (12 items) by testing the three abovementioned models ( Table 2) . Regardless of the specific subject area, the "Intercorrelation between the two concepts" model fitted the empirical data and was more satisfactory than the other two models (i.e., the 'distinct concepts without intercorrelations', and the 'one single dimension accounting for both concepts' model). The adjustment indices such as Chi square/df (French sample range: 2.09 to 2.18, Italian sample range: 6.09 to 7.35), the NFI, NNFI, CFI, CFI robust, IFI (range: .91 to .95, both samples) as well as the RMSEA (from .06 to .08) were all satisfactory (Table 2) . Moreover, with only one degree of freedom less (from to 54 to 53), the Chi square value from the "Intercorrelation between the two concepts" model was notably lower irrespective of the specific subject area (e.g., French sample Math range: 208.98 to 110.90, Italian sample Math range: 1095.58 to 389.65, Table 2 ). Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analyses (MCFA) were also carried out on the questionnaires using French and Italian samples, by testing the "Intercorrelation between the two concepts" model for each subject area, Math and First Language (French/Italian) separately. The results were very satisfactory using the hierarchical procedure for invariance across groups (i.e., factor loadings invariance, factor correlation invariance, and the invariance of item error variances, using equality constraints across groups). Even though the invariance of item error variances was trivial, MCFAs yielded a satisfactory model adjustment suggesting an invariance across French and Italian samples. In this last case, MCFA results presented satisfactory adjustment coefficients ranging from .90 to .92 for the NFI, NNFI, CFI, CFI and IFI indexes (Mueller, 1996; Joreskög & Sörbom, 1993) . The respective values for RMSEA (varying from .06 to .07) and Chi square/df (varying from 5.10 to 6.70) were also satisfactory (Byrne, 1989; Hofmann, 1995) . However, with respect to the Math subject, the Chi square/dl value was borderline. Regarding the correlations (Table 4) between the academic self-concept and the academic interest from both samples, the results showed significant coefficients (p<.01) for both subject areas, Math (French sample: .49 and Italian Sample: .70) and First Language (French: .51 and Italian: .64). Regardless of the academic concept, the coefficients of correlation between Math and First Language (French/Italian) were low or non-significant (from .01 to -.19). With respect to academic achievement (French sample), the coefficients of correlation were higher with the academic self-concept (Math: .62 and French: .66) compared to the academic interest (Math: .27 and French: .36).

The objectives of this study were to describe and to validate the academic self-concept and academic interest questionnaires with two European student samples (French and Italian), and to verify which theoretical model describing the relationship between academic selfconcept and academic interest best fitted the data. Another objective was the evaluation of correlations between academic concepts and academic achievement with one sample (French sample).

Results from the Confirmatory Factor Analyses confirmed that each questionnaire entailed one conceptual dimension, whatever the subject area (Math, French or Italian) and the student sample. Each conceptual dimension was composed of six items and presented satisfactory internal consistency with alpha coefficients ranging from .73 to .89 for both samples. Confirmatory Factor Analyses also enabled us to confirm which theoretical model best fit the data, by describing a correlation between the two concepts varying from .49 to .70. Even though the results revealed fairly high correlation coefficients between the two concepts when using Math and First Language as academic subjects, the academic self-concept and academic interest questionnaires still portrayed distinct characteristics. These results support the theoretical perspective which stipulates that academic self-concept consists of perceptions that arise through one's experience and are reinforced by significant others. Academic interest is more of a directive force, linked to the valence attached to a specific subject area, and is also the result of present and past experiences. In brief, despite certain similitudes between the two academic concepts, each of them holds distinct characteristics and should therefore be considered separately.

Furthermore, Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analyses allowed us to compare results from the French sample with those from the Italian sample in terms of factor loadings, factor correlations, and errors variances. Even though the invariance of errors variances is trivial and can be different according to the studied sample, the results yielded a significant invariance between samples with satisfactory adjustment fit indices. Contrary to Cokley et al.'s study (2003) , all MCFA results revealed a strong and robust factor structure of the academic selfconcept and academic interest questionnaires in both countries, France and Italy.

Regarding the correlation between academic achievement and both academic concepts within the French sample, the results showed that the academic self-concept in the same subject area was strongly correlated (from .62 to .66, p<.01), compared to the academic interest in the same subject area (from .27 to .36, p<.01). Furthermore, whatever the academic concept (academic self-concept or academic interest), it is important to consider the academic subject in order to observe a significant correlation with the grade. On the one hand, these results suggest that academic interest seems less significant than academic self-concept to explain academic achievement in a specific subject area. The former is related to the driving force whereas the latter is associated with self-competence. On the other hand, these results support those from Marsh's study (1992) , where the specific academic subject needs to be taken into consideration in order to establish a significant correlation between academic concepts (academic self-concept and academic interest) and academic achievement.

The main limitation of this study pertains to the difference in age and educational levels between the French and Italian samples. Even though the average age from the French sample was 12 compared to 18-19 for the Italian sample, the results from the Multi-Sample Confirmatory Factor Analyses with French and Italian samples have provided sufficient evidence that the factorial solution was robust regardless of educational level and age.

Overall, the results of this study support the conceptual link between academic selfconcept and academic interest, and also confirm the specificity of each academic concept. Further studies could attempt to replicate these results with students from other cultures and different educational levels. Finally, the next logical step would be to evaluate the predictive validity of the academic self-concept and academic interest questionnaires by adding academic achievement measures within a longitudinal design.

Le concept de soi scolaire et les intérêts scolaires sont des concepts importants pour comprendre le rendement scolaire des écoliers. Cependant, il y a peu de questionnaires disponibles qui ont été utilisés et validés dans plus d'un pays. La présente étude visait l'évaluation de ces concepts par l'utilisation du questionnaire du concept de soi scolaire (Marsh, 1990) et le questionnaire des intérêts scolaires (Corbière & Mbekou, 1997) Key words: Academic achievement, Academic interest, Academic self-concept, Multi-sample confirmatory factor analysis.

Note.

TABREF4.text: et ce, en considérant des échantillons français et italiens. Des analyses factorielles confirmatoires nous ont permis d'évaluer la structure factorielle des deux questionnaires concernant les matières scolaires -Mathématiques et Première langue (français ou italien) -et de déterminer quelles sont les directions théoriques entre les concepts. Les résultats des analyses factorielles confirmatoires sur les échantillons français et italien ont soutenu le modèle théorique en vertu duquel concept de soi scolaire et les intérêts scolaires sont corrélés et ce, tout en conservant leurs propres caractéristiques. Par ailleurs, les résultats d'analyses factorielles confirmatoires à échantillons multiples (échantillons français et italien) étayaient un modèle corrélationnel entre les deux concepts. Enfin, les résultats indiquaient une corrélation positive et significative entre le concept de soi scolaire, les intérêts scolaires et le rendement scolaire pour les deux matières scolaires (Mathématiques et Première langue).
